column274: it's a bit of a build and buy scenario. So what we are now doing
column275: which is become a very powerful in front of customers is
column276: we've taken many of our solutions and we started to integrate them in a more holistic way. So walking into a customer as opposed to buying all these point solutions
column277: there is an attractiveness of knowing that your data is going to flow from the beginning of a process that starts at maybe a quote or an underwriting decision on through the process
column278: so you can see it from a portfolio perspective in some of our catastrophe modeling solutions
column279: and all of that is information that's embodied in the solution at Sequel.The concept and the construct here is
column280: I can do it more effectively
column281: I can do it more efficiently and I can do it more accurately. And on top of that backbone
column283: I will refer to it the ISO and some of the other analytics that has been so powerful here in the States.So that continues to evolve. I think we'll be able to do more and more with customers as we gain access to more data
column284: and maybe just to take your question one step further
column285: to maybe highlight that -- I think we see London as being kind of a gateway into the international community
column286: especially with the specialty lines. So as we win these contracts
column289: but with companies who are located in UK
column290: but are underwriting business throughout the world. So our next step into other geographies is that much easier. -- Great. Thank you.Our next question comes from the line of David Togut from Evercore ISI. Your line is open. -- Thank you. Good morning. I'd like to ask about the Financial Services business
column291: which was really weak for the second year in a row. I'm wondering if this business has the same distinctives that really characterizing both your Insurance and your Energy and Specialized Markets businesses
column292: especially since competition here seems to be increasing with a number of well capitalized competitors like MasterCard offering more and more analytics to a credit card issuer.So my question really is
column293: does this business really still fit within Verisk
column294: especially given the broader capital allocation framework that you've rolled out today
column295: which seems to focus more on capital return? -- David
column297: the business does that. The -- I think that many of the folks on the call today are familiar with
column298: what we call our four distinctives
column299: which we talk about a lot
column300: which is just to remind everybody
column303: first mover advantage and deep embedment and customer workflows; and what we do in Financial Services has all four of those qualities. So as Lee previously talked about some of the things that have sort of moved through the business of late
column304: we talked about the sort of the lumpy quality of the way that some of the revenues have been recognized in the past. What I would go back to is
column305: that the heart of the business is built on consortium data
column306: which is absolutely unique and unlike the data
column307: which is available to anyone else
column308: including the players you just mentioned
column310: we have very deep relationships with our customers and really a large data platform
column311: which is really remarkable for a company of that size.So all of the conditions are there and then I would also say
column314: plus the spend analytics that we do
column315: are the leading parts of the business and they're actually healthy. So we expect that
column316: as these other effects sort of wash through
column317: you'll get sort of a more clear view of those things built upon the distinctives
column318: which really will power the business going forward. -- Thanks for that as a quick follow-up. I'd just like to ask about dividend policy. The math shows that the LTM payout ratio is about 28%. How do you think about the payout ratio that you're using to set the dividend and do you expect the dividend to grow in line with earnings or faster than earnings going forward? -- Thanks David
column320: let me take that. So we -- in setting that level
column321: we looked at the payout ratio
column322: really also what proportion of capital are we allocating to the dividend and an eye on kind of yield and where yields are out there. We recognize that investors will expect and reward growth in the dividend over time
column323: and we certainly believe that our ongoing earnings growth will provide a very strong consideration for these decisions by our Board in the future.We also expect to weigh capital investment and return opportunities in the allocation decisions ahead. So all of those I think factor into it
column324: but there clearly is a recognition that there will be an expectation
column325: given our overall growth that there -- that the dividend should grow as well. And that's what we will balance looking ahead in advises with the Board on these decisions. -- Thank you very much. -- Thanks David.Our next question comes from the line of Manav Patnaik from Barclays. Your line is now open. -- Thank you. Good morning. Scott
column326: I think at the beginning of the call
column327: you talked about the repurposing of 7B Insurance Consortium data
column328: and I was wondering if you can just expand on that
column329: maybe taking a step back and letting us know how much of the data do you have access now to play around and innovate with
column330: and if this is a new or ongoing opportunity? -- So let me start and Mark you may want to amplify some of this. But when we think about data and the Insurance vertical
column331: it's really a combination of looking for opportunities to tease additional meaning out of existing data sets and generating new datasets. So upfront
column333: subrogation. Subrogation is essentially bound up in the claims resolution process
column334: and as I think most folks know
column335: we have a lot of claims data. So finding a way to point that at the subrogation case and to think about affiliated things like clearing payment between counterparts
column336: is just interesting and it's really a process that hasn't really been transformed yet in the Insurance industry.So that would be an example of repurposing. But then there are other places where we're trying to generate original datasets. And one thing I would just comment on here is that
column337: on the one hand we are very alert to opportunities to position data to where it can be repurposed. On the other hand
column338: we are very diligent about the the reasons why our customers made the data available to us in the first place. And so we're going to always be striking a balance between the -- what's possible and what our customer contributors would like to see us do. But there's plenty of room in there for innovation. And then there are a variety of new data sets where we're making original calls for data. And you know
column340: even that takes a couple of forms. One is
column341: we have existing platforms like PCS where we started to call data related to cyber incidents
column342: and we didn't used to do that.So that's original data
column343: but around an existing platform. We are always trying to enrich the data that comes into a platform like claims search
column344: and then we're trying to find yet new forms of claims data that we don't receive today
column346: commercial claims histories are not as developed as personal claims histories. Mark
column347: anything you want to add to all that? -- I think that was well said. I think it goes back to the earlier comment I made about partnerships in conversations with CEOs. In the world of data
column349: our customers and many people feel their data is valuable. So we need to provide them with valuable use cases back to their businesses
column350: in order for them to let us use the data. So having the great partnerships and relationships is very important. We continue to be a trusted intermediary for that data
column351: and we feel that it's a privileged position. -- Got it and just for the follow-up. Lee
column352: Just on the Energy and Specialized side I think last year you guys called out
column353: I think it was a bank and then a merger related kind of headwind to the business. Have we lapped those comps and does that mean next year
column354: your number should start looking better? -- Thank you
column355: Manav. We will lap that in the first quarter of 2019. So we were still experiencing that headwind in the fourth quarter
column356: but that will go away in the first quarter of 2019. -- Next question.Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman from JP Morgan. Your line is open. -- Hi
column357: it's Andrew/ I wanted to ask about WoodMac 2.0 Lens. What are some milestone and rollouts that we should be looking for
column358: and will WoodMac 2.0 help margins and revenues or just one of them and particularly make a comment for 2019? -- Yeah
column359: so let me take it at a general level. Andrew
column361: if you want to add anything. It's constructive on both the revenue and the margin side
column362: because part of what Lens is getting after
column363: is the very nature of our data aggregation
column364: and it becomes more efficient on this platform that we've built. But equally
column365: there's more functionality there for customers and so we think it will be constructive in in both ways.I don't -- I wouldn't point you so much to milestones
column366: or at least not those that will be called out in the overall performance of the business. What I'm trying -- and I'm not making a comment about the future profile of the financial performance of the business. I'm simply saying
column367: the revenue streams are all sort of -- think of it as a bowl of spaghetti
column368: and Lens works its way through things that we already do
column370: new modules that we can license to customers. But I've called out specifics. Basically it will be -- we do business with so many companies already
column371: this will really enhance cross-selling into existing relationships. But in terms of visibility to the outside I'm not -- I wouldn't call out any particular milestone
column372: just the general progress of the business certainly. Lee
column373: anything you want to add that? -- No
column374: I think Scott covered it. I would just make the comment that Lens really represents the platform that enables us to continue the evolution of a very good research and consulting business into increasingly a data analytics business that can serve a broader customer base
column375: can develop and integrate data products more effectively
column376: which is beneficial both from a revenue growth standpoint
column377: as well as from a margin perspective. And I would just finally add that the team there continues to work on operational efficiencies
column378: to improve the margin as well. -- But Lee
column379: might there be a time like maybe this year where you're running two infrastructures for WoodMac and it might be a drag to margins ? -- Well
column382: but no. So you observe something
column384: I don't think is right. So yes we need to be running things in parallel and we have been investing
column385: as Lee has referenced several times
column386: to build the platform. But the actual operation of the platform
column387: I mean one of the things that's so constructive inside of our business
column388: is that we enjoy the gift of Moore's Law every day. And so actually
column389: the cost of compiling data or even processing data inside of the platform that you have built
column390: the incremental cost is not really all that great. I'm not saying that it's zero. So you're correct about what we will do operationally. But I think the implication you are trying to reach in terms of operating expense going forward is not so accurate. -- Yes
column391: and I would go more broadly. And I think that definitely has some relevance with regard to our transition to cloud
column392: where we are making investments and see opportunities to find greater efficiencies
column393: where we still have legacy costs. I think that is -- would be a valid observation
column394: not so much in this context. So thank you for the questions. -- Thanks.Our next question comes from the line of Tim McHugh from William Blair & Company. Your line is now open. -- Yes hello. First I wanted to ask on the Energy side of the business. In the prepared remarks
column395: you talked about being close designing to signing a consortium deal. Can you talk more about that and the nature of the data
column397: I guess that would flow out of it? -- Yeah. So those of you who have followed us
column400: a large majority of the data that we've had up until today
column401: has been mostly about the commercial dimensions of the oil and gas business. So observations about productivity and the cost factors associated with the assets that produce either the raw materials or the refined materials. So those are the datasets
column402: that have typically traditionally been a part of what we do. The datasets we are adding
column403: are what we call the sub-surface datasets
column404: and these are the ones that take into account the actual real-time operations
column406: in combination with the nature of the rock and the nature of the fluids and the nature of the fields. So that we can complement everything we've already done -- always done
column407: with basically much more real-time optimization of the operations of our customers' assets. And this is something that we haven't done as much of
column409: up till now. So the datasets relate to that; real-time operational optimization. -- And did you say it was for specific region or sub-sector of companies you would start with? -- Well you know -- so whenever we talk about the consortium dataset
column410: you're always -- you're always talking about specific customers and generally specific product sets or specific places. So that does apply in what we're doing in building these new datasets
column413: predominantly is the lower 48 in the United States
column414: where the need -- the situation in the United States is different than the situation in most other parts of the world
column416: what the operators are doing is basically saying
column417: that particular rig should I move it 2
column418: 000 feet and I can move it and four days later
column421: and so that's the speed with which 'strategy' is being set and operations are being rebalanced in the United States. -- Okay
column422: great. Thank you. And then just on the Insurance side
column424: can you -- and I think you mentioned it is one of the growth drivers
column426: but can you give us more color on adoption kind of competition for that product at this point? How it's scaling
column427: maybe relative to what the initial plan was 18 months ago or 12 months ago when you kind of made a more aggressive push into this space? -- Sure. So this is Mark. I think your question is directed at Insurance and at the same time
column428: we have been extendable (ph) beyond that. So first of all
column429: we've been very pleased with the takeaway we had in the market. Our market share is growing
column430: we've won significant customers and many of them that is clearly contributed to some of the organic growth that we've talked about here. Beyond what is -- I will refer to it as kind of market share
column431: we've also continued to add products. So remember in the world of
column432: what I view as a complete coordinated solution
column433: if I was to take and use imagery in combination with some of the scoping and what we refer to as image to scope
column434: which is the exact imaging tool behind or in-front of all this imagery
column435: we can really automate and become more accurate and more cost effective for those claims adjusters. Literally
column436: we think we can double the productivity of the claims adjuster field forces at our customer
column437: saving them hundreds of millions of dollars. So we're seeing that.What I also like to highlight though
column438: is that growth is extending beyond what is traditional Insurance. As you think about the world of contractors
column439: if you think about the world of -- I will refer to it as mapping and construction
column441: all of those have found use cases in some slimmed down or innovative way we view some of the technology. So that is contributing to the growth across the board
column442: even outside of Insurance. -- All right. Thank you.Our next question comes from the line of Bill Warmington from Wells Fargo. Your line is now open. -- Good morning
column443: everyone. -- Morning. -- So you mentioned the UK as a model and a gateway for international expansion. So culturally
column444: there's a lot of similarities in the US and the UK. I guess
column445: Winston Churchill would call them two nations divided by a common language. But as you go --as you look to prioritize your -- of the geographies for international expansion
column446: what are the ones where you are going to be focusing first? -- So
column447: I am going to assume that is a continuation of the conversation we had on Insurance. So
column448: we think there's a more to do in the UK. So we'll continue to push there. I think what we've identified is
column450: looking at places that have a more mature Insurance marketplace
column451: and a gross -- it's going to be a gross premium and a growing gross premium. We have really identified Europe
column452: but more specifically Germany and France as kind of the next couple of places that are of interest.Down the road
column453: and I think everyone thinks about kind of emerging markets -- emerging Insurance markets like China
column454: India. We aren't turning a back on that
column455: we are keeping an eye on it. But we kind of think to your point
column456: trying to stay close to the markets that are a little bit more mature in Europe is probably the best next step for us. -- Got it. Then for my follow-up
column457: your thoughts on FX impact to revenue in 2019? -- Yes. So Bill I know -- the reason that we try to focus on organic constant currency numbers is that
column458: we can't can't predict what's going to happen from an FX standpoint. So we're focusing on results
column459: excluding the FX range. I do think generally
column460: given the very strong US orientation of our business
column462: the fact that WoodMac has a mix of US and international revenues
column464: the exposure is relatively low. So I'd say proportionally
column465: we don't think it will have a big impact
column466: but our focus is always to try to eliminate that factor
column467: which we can't completely control. -- Got it. Thank you very much.Thank you. We have our next question from Jeff Meuler from Baird. Your line is now open. -- Yes
column468: thank you. As you productize the subsurface consortium data as you were just kind of explaining
column469: are you inventing new categories of solutions to sell to customers? And I don't mean new relative to Verisk
column471: new relative to the market? Or certain another way
column472: do you have to displace solutions from the leading incumbents that have subsurface data already
column474: I guess greenfield opportunities? -- It's a combination of the two and it really hinges upon how much analytic content we get into what we do. So there are players today and that will provide observations about a number of the sort of individual parameters that apply
column475: when you're trying to understand the productivity of real-time operations. So from one place you can get data that relates to
column477: the completion strategies that have been taken for the individual well. There are other sources where you can make sure that you have completely identified the leasing -- the leaseholding an ownership structure of whatever patch of land you're talking about
column478: and then other places you can go for the heavy seismology work
column479: and on and on and on like that.So part of what we will do is to increasingly make those kinds of those kinds of data available to our customers. But then
column481: what doesn't exist so much in the marketplace today is the -- is really the AI machine learned expression of all of that data in quantity across heterogeneous situations. So that in an automated fashion
column482: you can really make predictions and drive decisioning
column485: we will be distinguished. How much those kinds of solutions generate completely original revenue streams versus how much they displace
column487: some of these bespoke datasets. I would say that remains to be seen. The primary point here is
column488: there is the opportunity for differentiation. -- That's helpful. And then on the Insurance business
column489: there's been some underlying acceleration and there is a couple of years where maybe it was growing below trend a few years ago and you called out some various moment in time factors at that point. But I guess Scott
column490: as you list out the eight factors that are driving it
column491: they sound largely sustainable. So just how are you thinking about Insurance growth at this point. Like has bookings growth also accelerated
column492: is bookings growth outpacing revenue growth? Thanks. -- Yeah
column494: you definitely understood what I was saying upfront. All eight of those trends apply broadly across our company
column495: but specifically in the Insurance vertical. I mean
column496: if you just step back and you say OK
column498: what characterizes it? The customer set is relatively stable. There are occasionally some large merger transactions
column499: and there are some segments like global reinsurance brokers
column500: where there has been some of that seasonally. But by and large
column501: the customer demography is steady. Regulation really doesn't change that much. Energy -- excuse me
column503: as it relates to a company like us
column505: every -- virtually every one of our customers believes they can grow faster than their competitors. And so everybody is trying to behave innovatively
column507: that's just inherently constructive for folks like us.And then if you think about all of the -- the many references that we've made this morning
column508: they are just new things that we're doing and bringing to the market that don't exist. And so
column509: it's a constructive environment. I mean
column510: the United States Property and Casualty Insurance industry
column512: is the grand daddy of large-scale contributory data analytics. I mean it was invented that way practically. And so we really have this wonderful privilege of being who we are inside of that very constructive environment. -- Thank you
column513: Jeff. I think we have time for two more questions.Our next question comes from the line of George Tong of Goldman Sachs. Your line is now open. -- Hi
column515: good morning. I'd like to drill deeper into the Financial Services business; you touched on plans to reduce the variability of revenues through the restructuring of contracts. Can you elaborate on the initiatives you have to improve the overall growth of the segment? Because in the quarter
column516: even after normalizing for the year-ago implementation revenues associated with TSYS
column517: organic growth would have been pretty muted
column518: any color there would be helpful? -- Sure. So George
column520: and and I'm going to refer back to the kind of description in the organization that Lisa gave at Investor Day. And so
column521: I think it's helpful if you think about it in the four components. The foundation of this business is the benchmarking solutions business. And as we indicated
column522: the growth in that part of the business remains very stable. In addition
column523: the spend-informed analytics component remains solid. The two areas where in the fourth quarter and I think represent our opportunity to make progress
column524: is in the enterprise data management component
column525: and that really is an emerging space
column526: it is one where we are finding opportunities to develop new data management solutions for our customers. Given our scale
column528: and that's something that we certainly think
column529: based upon feedback from clients is very positive. But that is something that we will develop over time. We're encouraged by the initial responses.And the other element is the fraud component
column531: similarly where we -- I feel very good about the contributions from our acquisition of LCI and G2
column532: we are in the process of developing some of the infrastructure
column533: some of the product sets around that
column534: and we think that over time
column535: that area will also be a stronger contributor to the growth overall.So that would be the way I would kind of organize thinking around where we see or where we have a immediate focus on improving the growth rate for that business. -- Very helpful. As a follow-up. I'd like to switch over to the Energy business
column536: you saw an incremental step down in organic constant currency growth there
column537: can you talk about trends in your non-recurring revenue streams in Energy and how annualized contract value growth is progressing
column538: in light of some of the declines we've seen in  ? -- Sure. So I think in that -- that's principally the consulting -- consulting component business that was -- it was still growing and growing at a higher rate than our subscription business. But the third quarter was particularly strong
column539: and so I think that contributed at one level to a slight -- and I would just view it as kind of a slight slowdown relative to the third quarter level. But overall
column540: I think we see progress in this -- continued progress in the subscription component of the business
column541: particularly as it relates to to the new breakout initiatives that are generating strong subscription growth within that segment. -- I would just add
column542: the recent movement in the commodity is within a range that we don't consider it material to the performance of our business. -- Great
column544: George.Our last question comes from the line of Jeff Silber from BMO Capital Markets. Your line is now open. -- Thanks for sneaking me in. I'll be quick. Just a quick numbers questions
column546: what should we be modeling for interest expense this year
column547: and also the tax rate guidance that you gave us for 2019
column548: is that something we should view as longer term? Thanks. -- Yeah
column550: I think based upon what we see right now
column552: any changes in tax legislation. I think that 19% to 21% range is a good basis. On interest expense
column553: it's not something that we give formal guidance
column554: we -- obviously that's going to flex
column555: based upon what happens within the business and our capital allocation decisions. So
column556: I think kind of starting with the point of just stability in overall debt levels and looking at the average rates
column557: is probably a middle of the way road to go. But I wouldn't give you any specific guidance beyond that
column558: because that will adjust based upon our our capital allocation decisions over time
column559: I would expect that we remain within this -- within this leverage range
column560: absent any other material changes. -- Okay. Thanks so much. -- Okay. Well thank you all very much for your continued interest in Verisk
column561: and we look forward to following up with a number of you
column562: as well as those who are taking a new look at Verisk
column563: based upon our new capital policy
column564: including the dividend. So look forward to our continuing conversations with you. Thanks
column565: thanks for this morning and your attention. --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  --  -- Transcript powered by When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1:
hen President Trump implemented tariffs on imported solar cells and panels early in 2018, it was intended to drive a manufacturing renaissance in the U.S. and potentially hurt the overseas solar manufacturing industry. But  and solar panel prices are actually lower now than when tariffs were implemented, a strange turn for the industry.As tariffs make a measured decline from 30% now to 15% in 2021, they'll become even less of a headwind. Here's a look at where solar panel prices are today and who may be affected.Image source: Getty Images.The quarterly  put out by energy consultancy Wood Mackenzie and the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA) tracks the per-watt costs of solar cells and panels in the U.S., which reflect the impact of tariffs. The table below shows the change in cell and panel pricing over the past year, and you can see that prices are actually declining, despite tariffs going into place in Q1 2018.
  
Source:  .What drove prices lower had nothing to do with U.S. manufacturing or the tariffs themselves. It was the high demand late in 2017 that led to unusually high panel pricing, and a subsequent drop in demand after tariffs were implemented in the U.S. and  .By mid-2018, the solar industry had entered a new phase of oversupply, and global cell and panel pricing plunged. According to an analysis by the website EnergyTrend, solar panels can be purchased in tariff-free international markets for $0.22 per watt, an incredibly low price for solar products.While demand has picked up for solar panels as prices have fallen, we should expect fourth-quarter earnings and guidance for 2019 to be mixed, depending on a company's manufacturing capacity. (NASDAQ: CSIQ) and China's  (NYSE: JKS) are two of the largest solar manufacturers in the world, and I would expect both to report lower revenue per watt sold, although margins may not be as bad as you might think.The one benefit for some solar manufacturers is that component pricing is down even more than panel prices. You can see above that the spread between cell and panel pricing remained about flat over the past year, and polysilicon and wafer prices (components that go into making solar cells) are down significantly as well. That dynamic could actually help Canadian Solar's and JinkoSolar's margin percentage because both assemble more solar panels than the number of cells they produce.U.S. manufacturer  (NASDAQ: FSLR) , which benefited from tariffs because it was never subject to them, has reported weaker-than-expected guidance for 2019 because it's seeing lower panel pricing. It doesn't have the same component benefit as Canadian Solar or JinkoSolar may have because it manufactures the full solar panel. Ironically, it has been hurt more than most competitors by the supply-and-demand imbalance in 2018, and that will continue this year. (NASDAQ: SPWR) is one company that may see both sides of the pricing dynamic. The U.S. company makes everything from polysilicon to solar panels for some of its high-efficiency solar panels, which could see lower margins as panel pricing pressure hits the market in residential and commercial solar. But in power plants, it's buying commodity cells and assembling them into solar panels known as its P-Series, which could see better margins as component prices decline.As rough as 2018 was for solar companies, low component pricing is helping drive volume demand going into 2019 and beyond. In the U.S., Wood Mackenzie and the SEIA increased their 2020 to 2023 solar-installation guidance by 3.2 GW in the last quarter, due to a rush of utility-scale project signings. In China, JinkoSolar has already said it's seeing higher demand as panel prices decline.We've seen time and again that declining costs for solar components are far more important than any protective tariffs, and that showed in the U.S. in 2018. Expect falling costs to continue to be a driver of long-term solar growth. And if the policy environment improves in 2019, the U.S. could be a growth market once again.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. After all, the newsletter they have run for over a decade,  , has quadrupled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the  for investors to buy right now... and First Solar wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys. to learn about these picks!The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.@Solar Panels Are Cheap

n recent trading, shares of Verisk Analytics Inc (Symbol: VRSK) have crossed above the average analyst 12-month target price of $121.83, changing hands for $121.98/share. When a stock reaches the target an analyst has set, the analyst logically has two ways to react: downgrade on valuation, or, re-adjust their target price to a higher level. Analyst reaction may also depend on the fundamental business developments that may be responsible for driving the stock price higher - if things are looking up for the company, perhaps it is time for that target price to be raised.There are 12 different analyst targets contributing to that average for Verisk Analytics Inc, but the average is just that - a mathematical average. There are analysts with lower targets than the average, including one looking for a price of $100.00. And then on the other side of the spectrum one analyst has a target as high as $140.00. The standard deviation is $13.134.But the whole reason to look at the  VRSK price target in the first place is to tap into a "wisdom of crowds" effort, putting together the contributions of all the individual minds who contributed to the ultimate number, as opposed to what just one particular expert believes. And so with VRSK crossing above that average target price of $121.83/share, investors in VRSK have been given a good signal to spend fresh time assessing the company and deciding for themselves: is $121.83 just one stop on the way to an even  target, or has the valuation gotten stretched to the point where it is time to think about taking some chips off the table? Below is a table showing the current thinking of the analysts that cover Verisk Analytics Inc:
  
The average rating presented in the last row of the above table above is from 1 to 5 where 1 is Strong Buy and 5 is Strong Sell. The new solution is currently available in parts of Australasia, Asia, Europe and Canada.Using a unique algorithm, Black Box generates a risk score based on what customers state in the declaration of their medical conditions. The score can be used to complement an existing underwriting strategy.BB3 is the latest upgrade in Verisk's Black Box series (launched in 2000) and the scores generated indicate the chances of cancellation of claim, medical expenses and repatriation risk.It also comes with a new feature - Screening Lite, which controls the number of questions customers have to answer, based on the amount of risk associated with travel destinations and lead time - subject to insurer-determined criteria.BB3 is expected to help Verisk enhance its Insurance segment, which provides underwriting and ratings, and claims insurance data for the U.S. property and casualty ("P&C") insurance industry.Performance of the segment was strong in the las  ed quarter with revenues increasing 8% year over year on a reported basis and 5.5% organically and on an organic constant currency basis in the last reported quarter. column1: announced yesterday that it has inscribed an agreement to acquire business intelligence and software solutions provider for the London Insurance Market, Rulebook.The transaction price is fixed at $87 million, which will be funded through cash on hand and existing bank facilities.Through Rulebook Hub platform, Rulebook possesses a distinct pricing engine utilized for the purpose of internal pricing and underwriting as well as external distribution for the specialty insurance market. It also offers data analytics that provide business intelligence solutions to aid clients in historical, current, and predictive views of business operations.Mark Anquillare, chief operating officer, Verisk, stated, "Rulebook is a Verisk-like business that furthers our goal of providing leading solutions to the global insurance market, including a comprehensive chain of solutions to specialty insurers for mitigating risk and optimizing total cost of operations."The transaction is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2018, subject to customary closing conditions.Shares of Verisk have fared well in a year's time. The stock has rallied 30% compared with the  's rise of 9.9%.We believe that the buyout will boost the Insurance segment that offers analytics in the areas of fraud detection, catastrophe modeling, loss estimation and underwriting. Performance in the segment was particularly strong in the last reported quarter with revenues of $427.7 million, up 8% year over year on a reported basis and 5.5% at organic constant currency (cc).In the segment, underwriting and rating revenues of $285.1 million rose 8.9% on a reported basis and 6.3% at organic cc.Verisk estimates the transaction to be accretive to the company's adjusted EPS in 2019. Also, the company expects the buyout to generate an attractive return in excess of the company's cost of capital.Currently, Verisk carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). This is essentially a reflection of how the covering analysts have collectively reassessed their initial estimates over this period.Investors should keep in mind that the direction of estimate revisions by each of the covering analysts may not always get reflected in the aggregate change.Estimate revisions ahead of a company's earnings release offer clues to the business conditions for the period whose results are coming out. This insight is at the core of our proprietary surprise prediction model -- the Zacks  (Expected Surprise Prediction).The Zacks Earnings ESP compares the Most Accurate Estimate to the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter; the Most Accurate Estimate is a more recent version of the Zacks Consensus EPS estimate. The idea here is that analysts revising their estimates right before an earnings release have the latest information
column9: which could potentially be more accurate than what they and others contributing to the consensus had predicted earlier.Thus

column1:
n recent trading, shares of Verisk Analytics Inc (Symbol: VRSK) have crossed above the average analyst 12-month target price of $123.55, changing hands for $123.88/share. When a stock reaches the target an analyst has set, the analyst logically has two ways to react: downgrade on valuation, or, re-adjust their target price to a higher level. Analyst reaction may also depend on the fundamental business developments that may be responsible for driving the stock price higher - if things are looking up for the company, perhaps it is time for that target price to be raised.There are 11 different analyst targets contributing to that average for Verisk Analytics Inc, but the average is just that - a mathematical average. There are analysts with lower targets than the average, including one looking for a price of $105.00. And then on the other side of the spectrum one analyst has a target as high as $135.00. The standard deviation is $10.376.But the whole reason to look at the  VRSK price target in the first place is to tap into a "wisdom of crowds" effort, putting together the contributions of all the individual minds who contributed to the ultimate number, as opposed to what just one particular expert believes. And so with VRSK crossing above that average target price of $123.55/share, investors in VRSK have been given a good signal to spend fresh time assessing the company and deciding for themselves: is $123.55 just one stop on the way to an even  target, or has the valuation gotten stretched to the point where it is time to think about taking some chips off the table? Below is a table showing the current thinking of the analysts that cover Verisk Analytics Inc:
  
The average rating presented in the last row of the above table above is from 1 to 5 where 1 is Strong Buy and 5 is Strong Sell. column244: but basically they're using the data to model and they're finding great lift in pricing policies using that industry or data exchange. So early days

column247: that we all think that IoT is happening
column248: but probably at a slower pace than what we've seen in Europe and elsewhere. We remain optimistic and we'd love the position well. -- Thanks
column249: guys.Your next question comes from the line of Toni Kaplan with Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead. -- Hi

column288: it's not really any one thing
column289: it's really broadly based. -- Thank you.Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Steinerman with JP Morgan. Please go ahead. -- Hi
column290: it's Andrew. I wanted to talk about two things around Argus. I know it's a smaller business for you. The first one. Scott

column297: so to your question about the models. That comments in my remarks was it related to financial services and Argus specifically. And what's going on there just sort of reprieve that real quick is
column298: that in the face of mounting regulation
column299: the amount of documentation that is required on some of your models
column300: if your bank or you are a credit card issuer have really
column302: we had created some offerings that were pretty popular with our customers and that summarize the lot into
column303: what we call a wallet share model. And so if you're going to use sort of a wallet share model
column304: what the regulators have said is
column305: you cannot sort of operate that as a black box
column306: you're going to have to show us what's inside of your black box.And so the -- sort of the burden for our customers of opening up the black box really got sort of pretty large. And so in the face of that
column308: we have essentially disaggregated some of those models and sort of essentially taken the attributes which build up into the overall view
column309: and that's what we are now making available to our customers. So
column310: I just want everybody to understand that's the movement. So
column312: but the way it gets presented has had to change. And then to your question
column313: so in the third quarter of 2018
column314: the net effect of moving -- some of our customers moving away from the wallet share models and moving into the attributes was essentially a drag on the revenue line in the third quarter. So the transition is not yet complete.What that means is
column315: actually that there is upside for us going forward. We're feeling -- we have felt over the last couple of quarters the burden of that transition
column317: that's going to eventually even out or even move in the right direction. -- And Scott
column318: I asked about the eight contracts from Analyst Day. -- Michael
column319: let me take that one. So the answer is
column321: there has been a portion of those contracts that we have executed and have begun generating revenue. And then there have been a portion that has fallen out. I appreciate you're assiduousness in tracking that. It's not something that we are tracking on a regular basis
column322: we're obviously looking at kind of the current portfolio. But we have realized some of those contracts and some of those

column324: but I don't have those numbers in front of me. -- Okay
column325: much appreciated. Thank you. -- Thank you.Thank you. Your next question comes from the line of Ham's Maseru with Macquarie Capital. Please go ahead. -- Good morning and thank you. My question is just around pricing. Just given inflation and the system
column327: given your investment in data sets. Are you guys thinking about pricing differently than when you are owned by the insurance companies versus even just before you had Gemini. Just any sense on pricing philosophy and how that has changed and what we should think about going forward? -- Yeah. Our pricing philosophy is the same as it's always been
column328: which is that we price to value. So
column329: we're very focused on the utility of our solutions for our customers
column330: and it's on that basis that we set the prices for solutions that we provide. And as has always been the case
column331: our preference and the heart of our model is recurring subscriptions. And we find that that's good for our customers. They like knowing with some certainty what they're going to be paying for our solutions and it's good for us because of the visibility in the recurrence. So
column332: we normally try to -- that's where we try to set our pricing model.There are some occasions where with newer solutions
column333: particularly the customers would prefer that we started out transaction price
column334: because they don't really know exactly how much of that they're going to consume as they begin using it. And so
column335: we're perfectly happy to do that when that's what the customers want. But we generally find with times that they would like us to transition to subscription. And then the last thing I'll add is
column336: as a part of our pricing philosophy
column337: that we generally attempt to achieve mufti-year subscriptions with price inflates on an annual basis
column339: most of what we do is so basic to what our customers do it so embedded in their work flows that
column340: it's just -- there's just sort of a mutual understanding that this is the way business is going to get done.And so our customers are comfortable with signing mufti-year agreements. And of course for us
column341: that just represents an even higher level of recurrence. So everything I just said
column342: has been a part of our of our approach since October of 2009
column343: when you first saw us as a public company
column344: and I'm very certain that will remain our go-to-market approach. -- Great. And just a follow-up question. I know you touched on healthcare a bit around insurance
column345: maybe just remind us how much of your business today is not a P&C insurance? Specifically

column374: we can do it offline. Thank you.Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust. Please go ahead. -- Hi

column384: maybe shorter term or intermediate term? I assume longer term is not as big an impact? But I just wonder

column387: just all the way to the top

column390: it's really not a very large number. But also bear in mind that there are new entrants into the insurance space on a consistent basis and several of these are what get referred to as the insured tax. Sometimes
column391: they're innovating based upon the way that they segment the market
column392: you have some innovation in terms of
column394: peer-to-peer forms of insurance which are kind of interesting
column395: but they haven't really -- they haven't expressed themselves yet as particularly big trends.But think of it as an industry

column399: but there is also entry at the other end of the market. We do -- we have done very well with the new entrants. They find it really helpful to be able to make use of our methods as they get started. They are efficient
column400: it helps them get into business quickly
column401: it's actually a credibility for them as they do their business et cetera. So
column402: as we talk about sort of the evolution -- and this is very real-time. What I'm describing here is these new companies come into the market
column403: we find that they are vary inclined to work with us.When consolidations occur
column405: my emphasis here would be to how relatively few of them happen. But when they do occur
column406: it's very situation specific in terms of what it does to our business. There maybe some cases
column407: where the two companies coming together have -- they're very overlapping in their use of various solutions. And in that case
column408: they very reasonably expect to that like-on-like there might be some reduction in the total invoiced amount for the solution that the two companies were using and now the one aren't using. But there are frequently offsets to that also
column409: because it's also the case that one company maybe using our solutions and the other company is not. And in those cases
column410: actually there is a very nice cross-sell opportunity within that same account.And so
column411: when we go through these transitions with our customers were two become one. We dig in very deeply and talk to them about everything that they're using that comes from us and the things that they're not. There can be an effect
column413: although not particularly large. And then on an ongoing basis
column415: the profile of the account going forward
column416: the growth profile is -- I think
column417: Mark check me on this. But I think is generally about the same as it was before the two companies became one. So
column418: we note consolidation. And as I say
column419: it's very situation specific. But it's not a major effect on our business
column420: anything you want to add to that? -- I think the only thing -- I think you were trying to get a little feel for it. I think
column421: we feel that 2017 on the primary side of things
column422: it was kind of business is normal. I think

column431: but that's actually the most constructive kind of consolidation I can imagine for us -- constructive for us. -- That's certainly helpful. Thank you. And Scott

But we certainly see continued progress in that strength and the improvement in subscription growth supplemented by the breakout subscription growths which are at a high level. So

column482: that reflects the impact of that loss of that large global investment bank. And so

column484: that's kind of roughly a percentage point drag from a growth standpoint. -- Okay
column485: thank you. -- Okay.Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Meuler with Baird. Please go ahead. -- Yeah
column486: thank you. A couple the segment level margin questions. So first

Those are proceeding as we expect. The WoodMac 2.0 will be an investment cycle that certainly existed in 2018 and will persist through 2019 as we expand that platform and in that we are already beginning to see some benefits of that within the business. But there will be continued CapEx investment
column531: continued OpEx investment in that through 2019. And so

column535: headcount growth was I think a little lower this quarter
column536: having brought on some of the development folks that we needed on that front. And so
column537: that contributed to the clear improvement in margin that we saw in the third quarter. -- Thank you.Your next question comes from the line of Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo. Please go ahead. -- Good morning
column540: just a clarification on the storm contribution adjustment. I know that last year was a major year for storms and outsized gains from that. But there were also severe storms in the third quarter of '18. And so
column542: how much storm revenue -- was there -- the storm revenue contribution from the third quarter of '18 also backed out. I just want to understand the mechanics of that adjustment? -- So Bill
column543: I guess our view is that 2017 was truly an exceptional year. There's always going to be severe weather. '18 is going to be in our mind there was something really strange happens here at the latter part of the years
column544: its going be a normal year of severe weather. So
column545: I don't think we see anything adjusted or any adjustments to normalization in '18. We've been focused on '17
column546: because of the exceptional aspect. Let me just remind everybody
column547: the way many of our contracts
column548: specifically the Xactware repair cost estimating contracts work is
column549: that we provide access to the solution for a number of claims. And then when you quit a threshold
column550: you then get charged per claim at excess rate. It takes quite a substantial threshold or number of volume -- out of volumes to get above that threshold. I don't think we're going to see much of that in '18
column551: '17 was noteworthy. -- And then from my follow up
column552: Nielsen has been talking about how the GDPR regulation has been negatively impacting their marketing effectiveness business. And I know that they're a big user of the Argus data. And the Argus organic revenue growth showed a nice rebound in the third quarter. So
column554: is that rebound taking place despite or even with that GDPR headwind. Is that something that you're seeing that you're able to overcome? -- Yes
column555: so GDPR is a contextual factor for us
column556: but not one that I can say is really interacting with our results near term. And as long as we protect our data assets
column557: the way that we have and
column558: I expect we will. I do not believe there it will be a material impact going forward. So
column559: I can't comment on somebody else's control of the effective of the regulation. But where our business is concerned
column560: the primary effect of it at the interface with our customers is
column561: we have an extended discussion about contracts because we need to now talk about the assignment of liability at a higher level. We always had to talk about it
column562: but we talked about it more than we used to. That's really the only effect that I see. And it's not material. -- Got it. Well
column564: and Happy Halloween. -- Thank you.Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with Bank of America. Please go ahead. -- Hi
column566: I guess the first question. When I look back to the beginning of 2017
column568: you've had a significant investment cycle here
column569: 20 some acquisitions in the meaningful internal step up things like Geomni
column571: et cetera. Can you just frame for us
column572: how you think about the returns to the business that this investment cycle will deliver going forward. And I guess
column575: should we think of this as incremental to revenue growth or really just bolstering the business
column576: so it can continue to deliver. How do we think about the step down in margins and how that may trend over time and anything about how you're thinking about the return on this? Thank you. -- Right
column578: I'll ask Lee to talk about margins in a moment. But with respect to the investments that we've made
column580: they go in the direction of putting us into new categories of solution sets that we otherwise either haven't provided or we have provided in ways that haven't fully expressed what it is we can do for customers. So for example
column581: the acquisition of PowerAdvocate puts us in a category of spend analytics for the energy vertical that we weren't doing before. The Sequel acquisition puts us in a position to serve the London market
column582: particularly with respect to complex commercial risks in a way that we weren't able to serve it before. And then
column583: all the investments that we've done in Geomni
column584: we were in the category of interpreting remote imagery into datasets into analytics for our customers.The issue that we had was

column588: that is very much aimed at putting us into a new and different position for enhanced revenue growth on the top line. So -- and then other internal investments

column590: but it also makes us more capable in front of our customers. So
column591: very much it is about contributing to incremental growth of our business. Its not about the maintenance of things that we already do.And that is also really part of our feeling about the likely returns of these investments that we're making
column594: most everything we do is scalable. So
column595: as these investments mature and the revenues grow
column596: I would expect to see it be constructive with respect to margin. And also
column597: even if you look at more than just say a quarter and maybe Lee
column598: you want to pick up here a little bit. You know
column599: we still see constructive progression in the organic EBITDAs inside of our business relative to the organic revenue growth rates. -- I would just just quickly add
column600: in addition to what Mark described to develop new sources of revenue growth or enhance the revenue growth that we're generating off of our data. We are also making investments for instance in cloud modernization that we think will yield overall improved returns on capital and improved margins for us. So
column601: we are making those types types of investments as well. And we look at each of those investments on the basis of what type of return are we generating
column602: whether it's through savings or through incremental profitability. So thanks

column604: so you've lapped three of the four chunkier
column605: larger acquisitions from 2017 during this quarter. I know you don't like to talk about forward margin trends. But is there anything you'd call out that would lead us from believing the reasonable pathway here as to having lapped a lot of that drag that there's been in your profitability goes away at this point or soon? I realize you've got a tough comp in Q4 with the Insurance comparison
column606: but anything else you'd call out or is it reasonable of having lapped a lot of that
column607: things look better from here? Thank you. -- So

column616: but we are narrowing that gap. -- Great. Thank you.Your next question comes from the line of Joseph Foresi with Cantor Fitzgerald. Please go ahead. -- Hi. I was wondering to what extent do you think you could provide -- and I don't want to take anything away from the Analyst Day

column1: stock has rallied 27.8% on a year-to-date basis, outperforming the 11.8% rise of the  it belongs to.Verisk's expertise in providing predictive data analytics decision by using advanced technologies to collect and interpret different types of data sets is impressive. The company mainly uses advanced technologies such as latest remote sensing and machine learning technologies along with cloud computing. The majority of the technologies used by Verisk are developed, maintained and supported by almost 20% of its employees. Its efforts to stay technologically updated to meet varying client demands and its technical prowess in analytics and Big Data provide Verisk an edge over its competitors.Higher organic revenue growth through a combination of increase in new customers for existing solutions, cross-sale of its existing solutions to existing customers and the sale of new solutions will help Verisk create long-term value. In the first nine months of 2018, total revenues grew 7% organically and 6.3% on an organic constant-currency basis. This marks an improvement from 2017 when total revenues grew 4.5% organically and 5.3% on an organic constant currency basis.Moreover, Verisk continues to earn a major portion of its revenues from subscriptions and long-term agreements. In the first nine months of 2018, Verisk's three reportable segments: Insurance, Energy and Specialized Markets and Financial Services generated a respective 81%, 78% and 72% of revenues from subscriptions and long-term agreements for its solutions.Acquisitions have also been one of the key growth catalysts for Verisk. The company has been continuously acquiring and investing in companies globally to expand its data and analytics capabilities across industries. In 2018 so far, the company has acquired three companies -Validus-IVC Limited on Jun 20, Business Insight Limited on Feb 21 and Marketview Limited on Jan 5. While the buyout of Validus will help improve and automate the claims settlement process, the other two acquisitions will help Verisk in its predictive analytics and consumer spending analytics decision making.Verisk's balance sheet is highly leveraged. As of Sep 30, 2018, long-term debt was $2.04 billion while cash and cash equivalents was $147.6 million. Such a cash position implies that Verisk needs to generate adequate amount of operating cash flow to service its debt. Also, high debt may limit the company's future expansion and worsen its risk profile.Since Verisk's business model centers on huge amount of data, it remains susceptible to operational risks related to security breaches at its facilities, computer networks, and databases, resulting in loss of its credibility and/or customers. Dependence on external sources for data supply can lead to contractual and pricing issues with data suppliers (some of them are also its rivals).Verisk currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can see  .A few better-ranked stocks in the broader  include Paychex, Inc.  , Genpact Limited  and WEX Inc.  , each carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). The long-term expected EPS (three to five years) growth rate for Paychex, Genpact and WEX is 8.5%, 10% and 15%, respectively.Last year, it generated $8 billion in global revenues. By 2020, it's predicted to blast through the roof to $47 billion. Famed investor Mark Cuban says it will produce "the world's first trillionaires," but that should still leave plenty of money for regular investors who make the right trades early.Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? Today, you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days. This is essentially a reflection of how the covering analysts have collectively reassessed their initial estimates over this period.Investors should keep in mind that the direction of estimate revisions by each of the covering analysts may not always get reflected in the aggregate change.Estimate revisions ahead of a company's earnings release offer clues to the business conditions for the period whose results are coming out. Our proprietary surprise prediction model -- the Zacks  (Expected Surprise Prediction) -- has this insight at its core.The Zacks Earnings ESP compares the Most Accurate Estimate to the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter; the Most Accurate Estimate is a version of the Zacks Consensus whose definition is subject to change. The idea here is that analysts revising their estimates right before an earnings release have the latest information

column1:
n recent trading, shares of Verisk Analytics Inc (Symbol: VRSK) have crossed above the average analyst 12-month target price of $120.80, changing hands for $120.97/share. When a stock reaches the target an analyst has set, the analyst logically has two ways to react: downgrade on valuation, or, re-adjust their target price to a higher level. Analyst reaction may also depend on the fundamental business developments that may be responsible for driving the stock price higher - if things are looking up for the company, perhaps it is time for that target price to be raised.There are 10 different analyst targets contributing to that average for Verisk Analytics Inc, but the average is just that - a mathematical average. There are analysts with lower targets than the average, including one looking for a price of $105.00. And then on the other side of the spectrum one analyst has a target as high as $130.00. The standard deviation is $10.622.But the whole reason to look at the  VRSK price target in the first place is to tap into a "wisdom of crowds" effort, putting together the contributions of all the individual minds who contributed to the ultimate number, as opposed to what just one particular expert believes. And so with VRSK crossing above that average target price of $120.80/share, investors in VRSK have been given a good signal to spend fresh time assessing the company and deciding for themselves: is $120.80 just one stop on the way to an even  target, or has the valuation gotten stretched to the point where it is time to think about taking some chips off the table? Below is a table showing the current thinking of the analysts that cover Verisk Analytics Inc:
  
The average rating presented in the last row of the above table above is from 1 to 5 where 1 is Strong Buy and 5 is Strong Sell. This article used  .  .The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.@Verisk Analytics Reaches Analyst Target Price@2018-10-04@https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/verisk-analytics-reaches-analyst-target-price-2018-10-04

nvestors in Verisk Analytics Inc (Symbol: VRSK) saw new options become available this week, for the June 2019 expiration. One of the key inputs that goes into the price an option buyer is willing to pay, is the time value, so with 239 days until expiration the newly available contracts represent a potential opportunity for sellers of puts or calls to achieve a higher premium than would be available for the contracts with a closer expiration. At  , our YieldBoost formula has looked up and down the VRSK options chain for the new June 2019 contracts and identified one put and one call contract of particular interest.The put contract at the $105.00 strike price has a current bid of $3.50. If an investor was to sell-to-open that put contract, they are committing to purchase the stock at $105.00, but will also collect the premium, putting the cost basis of the shares at $101.50 (before broker commissions). To an investor already interested in purchasing shares of VRSK, that could represent an attractive alternative to paying $114.81/share today.Because the $105.00 strike represents an approximate 9% discount to the current trading price of the stock (in other words it is out-of-the-money by that percentage), there is also the possibility that the put contract would expire worthless. The current analytical data (including greeks and implied greeks) suggest the current odds of that happening are 79%. Stock Options Channel will track those odds over time to see how they change, publishing a chart of those numbers on our website under the  . Should the contract expire worthless, the premium would represent a 3.33% return on the cash commitment, or 5.09% annualized - at Stock Options Channel we call this the  .Below is a chart showing the trailing twelve month trading history for Verisk Analytics Inc, and highlighting in green where the $105.00 strike is located relative to that history:Turning to the calls side of the option chain, the call contract at the $120.00 strike price has a current bid of $5.60. If an investor was to purchase shares of VRSK stock at the current price level of $114.81/share, and then sell-to-open that call contract as a "covered call," they are committing to sell the stock at $120.00. Considering the call seller will also collect the premium, that would drive a total return (excluding dividends, if any) of 9.40% if the stock gets called away at the June 2019 expiration (before broker commissions). Of course, a lot of upside could potentially be left on the table if VRSK shares really soar, which is why looking at the trailing twelve month trading history for Verisk Analytics Inc, as well as studying the business fundamentals becomes important. Below is a chart showing VRSK's trailing twelve month trading history, with the $120.00 strike highlighted in red:Considering the fact that the $120.00 strike represents an approximate 5% premium to the current trading price of the stock (in other words it is out-of-the-money by that percentage), there is also the possibility that the covered call contract would expire worthless, in which case the investor would keep both their shares of stock and the premium collected. The current analytical data (including greeks and implied greeks) suggest the current odds of that happening are 54%. On our website under the  , Stock Options Channel will track those odds over time to see how they change and publish a chart of those numbers (the trading history of the option contract will also be charted). Should the covered call contract expire worthless, the premium would represent a 4.88% boost of extra return to the investor, or 7.45% annualized, which we refer to as the  .The implied volatility in the put contract example is 26%, while the implied volatility in the call contract example is 22%.Meanwhile, we calculate the actual trailing twelve month volatility (considering the last 252 trading day closing values as well as today's price of $114.81) to be 18%. For more put and call options contract ideas worth looking at, visit StockOptionsChannel.com.The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.@Interesting VRSK Put And Call Options For June 2019@2018-10-25@https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/interesting-vrsk-put-and-call-options-june-2019-2018-10-25

arren Buffett's  (NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) manages a staggering $200 billion, and while Buffett is best known for his own-it-forever stock-picking approach, he's not afraid to sell companies when he feels his money can be best put to use elsewhere.Because Berkshire Hathaway's so big, it tends to own huge stakes in companies that take months to unwind, so the prospect of being on the wrong side of an investment Buffett's soured on isn't a pleasant one. Fortunately, the stocks Berkshire Hathaway is selling are revealed every quarter in a 13F report it files with the Securities and Exchange Commission. According to its latest disclosure,  (NASDAQ: VRSK) ,  (NYSE: PSX) ,  (NASDAQ: AAL) , and  (NYSE: UAL) all fell out of favor at Berkshire Hathaway last quarter.Berkshire Hathaway was one of the founders of Verisk Analytics back in the 1970s, and it was the only founding member of the company to hold on to all its shares when Verisk went public in 2009.IMAGE SOURCE: THE MOTLEY FOOL.In the second quarter, that long history came to an end. As I detailed in May, Verisk Analytics fell to an  position for Berkshire Hathaway in the first quarter of 2018 and, sure enough, Berkshire Hathaway unloaded its remaining 284,778 shares last quarter.Buffett's mum on why he decided now is the right time to sell, but the company's expansion into other markets that's reduced its reliance on property and casualty insurance clients like Berkshire Hathaway's GEICO could be a factor. It's also likely that Verisk Analytics rally to all-time highs this year made booking his gain too attractive. For perspective, the company IPO'd at $22 and its share price was recently north of $116.The fact Verisk Analytics has marched higher despite Berkshire Hathaway selling its shares is intriguing and now that Berkshire doesn't have anymore shares left to sell, it will be interesting to see what happens next for this company's share price. In the past, stocks such as  and  have ticked higher following Berkshire's exit. But Berkshire's stake in Verisk Analytics was markedly smaller than it was in those Goliaths and therefore Berkshire's selling likely wasn't much of a weight holding down Verisk's share price.Nevertheless, it might be worth keeping an eye on Verisk Analytics because its sales and earnings are growing. In Q2, revenue rose 15% to $601 million, including 7% organic constant currency growth, and earnings per share increased 29% to $1.06.
  
Positions current as of June 30, 2018. Data source: Berkshire-Hathaway SEC form 13F, filed Aug. 14, 2018.Perhaps Buffett's decision to sell more shares in Phillips 66, an oil and gas transport, storage, refining, and marketing company, this quarter was most surprising. Berkshire Hathaway sold 35 million shares of Phillips 66 in Q1. However, that decision appeared to be prompted by a desire to reduce Berkshire's stake below 10% to reduce regulatory burdens.Berkshire Hathaway came into the second quarter owning about 9.8% of Phillips 66, down from 16% previously, but apparently that wasn't small enough. In Q2, Buffett sold another 10.9 million shares, reducing Berkshire Hathaway's position by about 24% to 34.7 million shares.The decision to sell was made even as Phillips 66 shares were hitting new highs and ahead of second-quarter financial results that beat industry watchers' estimates on both the top and bottom lines. Specifically, the company's revenue rose 21% to $29.7 billion and its diluted EPS skyrocketed to $2.84 from $1.06 in Q2 2017. Its refining business was its best performer, generating $910 million in net income, up from $224 million one year ago.Often, significant selling of a stock by Berkshire Hathaway suggests its selling will continue. Because Phillips 66's refining capacity utilization was at 100% last quarter,  are near their highs, and Phillips 66's stock has been rallying, now could be a good time to book some profit in this stock, especially since Berkshire still owns a lot of shares it could sell.IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.Berkshire Hathaway bought a slate of airline stocks when it first included them in its portfolio in 2016, but recently, Buffett's been  his exposure to  (NYSE: LUV) and  (NYSE: DAL) and reducing Berkshire's holdings of American Air and United Continental.Rising jet fuel and nonfuel costs have dented the industry's profit margins in the past year and American's and United Continental's 9% operating margins significantly trail Southwest's and Delta's. American arguably has one of the least favorable balance sheets of the four because of a heavy debt load and worry costs could continue pressuring profit have made it a poor performer this year. Alternatively, United Continental's share price has rallied nicely in 2018, particularly following its second-quarter financial results. In the quarter, United Continental offset more of its costs with rising revenue per average seat mile than anticipated,  to up its full-year adjusted earnings-per-share guidance to at least $7.25 from at least $7 previously.Warren Buffett's preference for Southwest and Delta Air could indicate he's settled on those two as his favorite plays in the industry, and if so, investors might want to consider selling some of their shares in American and United Continental. As of June, Berkshire Hathaway still owns 26.7 million shares in United Continental and 44.7 million shares of American Airlines, so if he continues to unwind those positions, it could present a stiff headwind for their share prices.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. After all, the newsletter they have run for over a decade,  , has quadrupled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the  for investors to buy right now... and Berkshire Hathaway (A shares) wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys. to learn about these picks!The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.@Top Stocks Warren Buffett Is Selling Now@2018-08-15@https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/top-stocks-warren-buffett-selling-now-2018-08-15

's  Geomni business unit announced a technology partnership with digital visualization software developer Renoworks Software Inc., yesterday.Initially concentrated on manufacturer and material supplier markets, the duo will serve as mutual value-added resellers of their relevant product solutions.Jeffrey C. Taylor, president at Geomni, stated, "Renoworks visualization platform is the perfect distribution vehicle for Geomni's imagery analytics tools in the home construction market. Supporting this market by improving performance and creating significant impact in the value chain is a key strategy Geomni is pursuing to provide critical solutions for homeowners."Shares of Verisk have fared well in a year's time. The stock has rallied 47.4% compared with the  's rise of 26.1%.The partnership will integrate Geomni's expertise in detailed measurements and analytics with Renoworks' visualization services as well as extensive manufacturer product libraries to improve the design-to-project delivery process in construction and remodeling markets.This is expected to provide additional growth and innovation opportunities to the companies. | The collaboration is expected to boost Verisk's Insurance segment that includes aerial imagery and remote sensing solutions. Performance in the segment was particularly strong in the last reported quarter with revenues of $288.9 million increasing 12.3% year over year on a reported basis and 8.4% at organic constant currency (cc).In the segment, claims revenues of $140.5 million improved 16.7% on a reported basis and 13.2% at organic cc on the back of revenues from aerial imagery solution, repair cost estimating solutions as well as claims analytics.Currently, Verisk carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). A few better-ranked stocks in the broader  are WEX Inc.  , BG Staffing, Inc.  and Broadridge Financial Solutions, Inc.  , each carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).
